7:30 This segment made me realize another dimension of how my medical condition, postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome (POTS) works. The first recommendation physicians give is to intake more fluids and sodium to increase blood volume, which in turn--sometimes--increases blood pressure. This is important because in POTS we don't have the reflects around our veins to push blood back up to our hearts, so blood constantly drains down (fun stuff). So when I heard this segment I thought, "Screwy biology! Veins need higher pressure!" in regard to my particular condition. Sure, the circulatory system needs the pressure differences between arteries and veins, but it also sounds odd in a sense because at least arteries get to where they need to go because of gravity. Veins? Low pressure and gravity are my enemy.

because it's not labeled as if your staring at it, it's labeled how it would be staring at you which is the opposite

It's labelled relative to the anatomical position, imagine looking at the heart from his perspective with left and right flipped: that's because he's looking at another heart from front on, whereas if you were labelling this on your chest from your perspective in the anatomical position, left is left and right is right.  Basically, he's looking at this anteriorly, so it looks flipped and it's what a cardiologist sees when looking at your heart. You would more clearly see it posteriorly (from behind you) where both you and your heart are facing the right direction, where left is left and right is right.

No, it is not blue.  Deoxygenated blood is more of a deep maroon color, compared to the brighter red of oxygenated blue.  As you hypothesized, diagrams that show deoxygenated blood as blue are just using artistic licence to make the difference more "clear" (though it reinforces a common misconception in the process!)

There are multiple auricles in your body.  One type is in the ear, the other are located in the atria.  Your Right and Left atria each have an outer wrinkly flap.  This helps with the expansion of the atria when they are filled with blood.  Because the walls of the atria are so thin, especially in comparison to the Left Ventricle, they expand easily.  When these chambers are not filled with blood, or deflated, the outer portion of each atrium deflates into that wrinkly flap called the auricle.

I really like this video but CO2 is important. We need it to help regulate our blood pH. That is why hyperventilation is bad. We get too much oxygen and our blood pH goes up, we need more CO2 to be able to lower the pH back to the normal range. so CO2 does do our bodies a little bit of good.

Pulmonary veins attach to the left atrium which is oxygenated blood and therefore pumping from the lungs into the heart and out toward the rest of the body. If blood goes down its pressure gradient (from high to low) the pressure within the pulmonary veins would need to be higher than that in the atrium for blood to enter it. Veins have less pressure than arteries also the pulmonary vessels differ from vessels throughout the body and yes only veins have valves.

This video reminds me of a little mnemonic I thought of way back in school to help me remember the circulation of blood through the heart: "You gotta try to breathe, right?"  Try = tri = tricuspid valve Breathe = lungs Right = right side of the heart  (the right side of the heart sends blood to the lungs, and the tricuspid valve is on the right side of the heart - by elimination, the bicuspid valve and blood going to the rest of the body is on the left)
